Title: [L06] Inconsistent hasPrice determination
Content:
The [`hasPrice` function of the `OptimisticOracle` contract](https://github.com/UMAprotocol/protocol/blob/1631ef7ad29aaeba756ef3b9a01c667e1343df85/packages/core/contracts/oracle/implementation/OptimisticOracle.sol#L494-L494) returns `true` if the request is either `Settled` or `Resolved`. Although the internal state of the contract does not record the price in the `Resolved` state, this makes sense because [retrieving the price will settle the request](https://github.com/UMAprotocol/protocol/blob/1631ef7ad29aaeba756ef3b9a01c667e1343df85/packages/core/contracts/oracle/implementation/OptimisticOracle.sol#L407). This means that from a userâ€™s point of view, a `Resolved` price request [can be considered to have a price](https://github.com/UMAprotocol/protocol/blob/1631ef7ad29aaeba756ef3b9a01c667e1343df85/packages/core/contracts/oracle/implementation/OptimisticOracle.sol#L543). However, the same reasoning suggests that an `Expired` price request [can also be considered to have a price](https://github.com/UMAprotocol/protocol/blob/1631ef7ad29aaeba756ef3b9a01c667e1343df85/packages/core/contracts/oracle/implementation/OptimisticOracle.sol#L538).


Consider adding another condition to the `hasPrice` function so it returns `true` for `Expired` price requests.


**Update**: *Fixed in [PR#2319](https://github.com/UMAprotocol/protocol/pull/2319).*
